case_id: Madan v. State of Rajasthan, Criminal Appeal No. 1655 of 2023 (Supreme Court of India, Decided: 31 May 2023)
facts: Incident occurred on 28.06.2009 around 10:00 PM in Village Lalas, Tehsil Ladnun, District Nagaur, Rajasthan.
A dispute arose over drainage water ('nali') near the house of the complainant, PW-1 Bhanwar Lal.
Accused persons (Madan - Appellant, Dana Ram, Mangu Ram, Bhagu Devi, Lichhma Devi) allegedly attacked Ramnarayan (son of PW-1) with lathis.
Appellant Madan specifically alleged to have hit Ramnarayan on the head with a lathi.
FIR lodged by PW-1 on 29.06.2009 initially under Sections 147, 148, 149, 323, 341, 447 IPC at PS Ladnun.
Victim Ramnarayan admitted to Govt. Hospital, Ladnun, referred to Bikaner, and died on 30.06.2009 during treatment.
Post-mortem conducted on 01.07.2009 (PW-12 Dr. Ramavtar Swami) revealed cause of death as coma due to ante-mortem head injury.
Following the victim's death, Section 302 IPC was added to the investigation.
Trial Court (Sessions Judge, Merta) framed charges against all 5 accused under Sections 148, 302, 302/149, 323/149, 341/149 IPC.

Trial Court Judgment (31.05.2012): Acquitted Dana Ram, Mangu Ram, Bhagu Devi, Lichhma Devi. Convicted Appellant Madan under Section 302 IPC; acquitted him of other charges (148, 302/149, 323/149, 341/149). Sentenced Madan to Life Imprisonment and fine.
High Court Judgment (02.11.2017): Dismissed Madan's appeal, confirming the conviction under Section 302 IPC and the sentence.
Madan filed the present appeal before the Supreme Court challenging the High Court's judgment.
Key prosecution evidence included testimony of eyewitnesses PW-1 (Bhanwar Lal - father), PW-2 (Santosh - mother), PW-3 (Manju - sister) and medical evidence (post-mortem report).
Supreme Court noted the fight arose suddenly over a trivial dispute, involved a single blow by the appellant with a lathi, and no prior enmity indicating intent to kill was established.
ipc_sections: Section 149 (Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object)
Section 304 (Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder - Parts I and II discussed)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Eyewitnesses PW-1, PW-2, and PW-3 consistently testified that the appellant Madan inflicted the fatal head injury on the deceased Ramnarayan with a lathi. Their testimonies are reliable and corroborated by medical evidence.
precedents: Leela Ram v. State of Haryana (1999) 9 SCC 525 (Related witnesses are not inherently unreliable)
State of U.P. v. Krishna Master (2010) 12 SCC 324 (Minor discrepancies do not discredit otherwise trustworthy eyewitness testimony)
Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1953 SC 364 (Relationship is not a disqualification for a witness if testimony is credible)
elements: Presence of eyewitnesses at the scene
Observation of the specific act by the appellant (hitting head with lathi)
Corroboration by medical evidence (head injury as cause of death)

counter_arguments.loophole: The primary eyewitnesses are close relatives (father, mother, sister) of the deceased, making them interested witnesses whose testimony requires careful scrutiny and independent corroboration, which might be lacking.
supporting_precedents: Kali Ram v. State of H.P. (1973) 2 SCC 808 (Heavy burden on prosecution; need for caution with interested witnesses)
Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras AIR 1957 SC 614 (Classification of witnesses and need for corroboration for 'partly reliable' witnesses)
Sarwan Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1957 SC 637 (Testimony of related witnesses needs careful scrutiny)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The act of inflicting a forceful lathi blow on the head, a vital part of the body, demonstrates the intention to cause such bodily injury as is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, bringing the act squarely under Section 300 Clause Thirdly (Murder), justifying the conviction under Section 302 IPC.
precedents: Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1958 SC 465 (Laying down the requirements for Section 300 Clause Thirdly)
Anda v. State of Rajasthan AIR 1966 SC 148 (Intention to cause the specific injury inflicted is sufficient, not necessarily intention to cause death)
State of A.P. v. Rayavarapu Punnayya (1976) 4 SCC 382 (Explaining the distinction between murder and culpable homicide based on degree of intent/knowledge)
elements: Injury was caused by the accused (Madan)
Accused intended to cause that particular bodily injury
The injury was objectively sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death

counter_arguments.loophole: The incident was a sudden fight without premeditation, involving a single blow with a common object (lathi). This negates the specific murderous intent required for S.302, suggesting the offence is more likely Culpable Homicide under S.304 (possibly Part II, based on knowledge).
supporting_precedents: Rampal Singh v. State of U.P. (2012) 8 SCC 289 (Single blow cases in sudden fights often fall under S.304)
Pulicherla Nagaraju @ Nagaraja Reddy v. State of A.P. (2006) 11 SCC 444 (Factors like single blow, nature of weapon, lack of premeditation differentiate S.302 from S.304)
Chamru Budhwa v. State of M.P. AIR 1954 SC 652 (Conviction altered from S.302 to S.304 Part II in a case of death by single lathi blow)

defense_arguments.argument: The conviction under Section 302 IPC is erroneous as the incident occurred due to a sudden quarrel over a trivial issue (drainage water) without premeditation. The act falls under Exception 4 to Section 300 IPC (culpable homicide committed in a sudden fight in the heat of passion upon a sudden quarrel).
edge_cases: Establishing the 'suddenness' of the fight and lack of premeditation.
Proving that the appellant did not take undue advantage or act in a cruel or unusual manner.
precedents: Sukhbir Singh v. State of Haryana (2002) 3 SCC 327 (Detailed analysis of requirements for Exception 4 to S.300)
Surinder Kumar v. Union Territory, Chandigarh (1989) 2 SCC 217 (Single blow in a sudden quarrel can attract Exception 4)
Ghapoo Yadav v. State of M.P. (2003) 3 SCC 528 (Application of Exception 4 requires assessment of suddenness, lack of premeditation, and absence of undue advantage/cruelty)

defense_arguments.argument: The appellant lacked the requisite intention (mens rea) for murder under Section 300 IPC. He used a lathi, not an inherently deadly weapon, and delivered only a single blow during a sudden altercation. At most, he could be attributed with the knowledge that such an act was likely to cause death, making the offence fall under Section 304 Part II IPC.
edge_cases: Distinguishing 'intention to cause death' or 'intention to cause injury sufficient to cause death' (S.302 / S.304 Part I) from mere 'knowledge that the act is likely to cause death' (S.304 Part II).
Assessing the nature of a lathi blow to the head in terms of implied intent versus knowledge.
precedents: Chamru Budhwa v. State of Madhya Pradesh AIR 1954 SC 652 (Single lathi blow case altered from S.302 to S.304 Part II)
Gurmail Singh v. State of Punjab (1991) 1 SCC 189 (Factors like single injury, weapon used, and circumstances considered for altering S.302 to S.304)
Ananta Kamilya v. State of West Bengal (2020) 2 SCC 535 (Recent precedent altering conviction from S.302 to S.304 Part II based on sudden quarrel and single blow)

defense_arguments.argument: The testimonies of the closely related eyewitnesses (PW-1, PW-2, PW-3) suffer from contradictions and embellishments, making them unreliable for grounding a conviction for a capital offence like murder, especially when other accused were acquitted based on similar evidence.
edge_cases: Quantifying the significance of testimonial discrepancies.
Arguing that acquittal of co-accused casts doubt on the reliability of witnesses against the appellant as well.
precedents: State of Rajasthan v. Kalki (1981) 2 SCC 752 (Relationship doesn't discredit, but careful scrutiny is essential)
Alamgir Sani v. State of Assam (2002) 10 SCC 277 (Where evidence is same, acquittal of some accused may benefit others unless specific distinguishing evidence exists)
Bihari Nath v. State of M.P. (1996) 11 SCC 421 (Significance of contradictions in eyewitness accounts)

judgment.outcome: Appeal partly allowed. The conviction of the appellant Madan under Section 302 IPC was set aside and altered to conviction under Section 304 Part II IPC. The sentence of Life Imprisonment was modified to Rigorous Imprisonment for 7 years.
reasoning: The Supreme Court accepted the concurrent findings of the Trial Court and High Court regarding the appellant Madan being the assailant who caused the head injury to the deceased, based on consistent eyewitness testimonies (PW-1, PW-2, PW-3) corroborated by medical evidence.
The Court determined that the crucial issue was whether the offence constituted Murder (S.302) or Culpable Homicide Not Amounting to Murder (S.304).
The Court noted the incident arose from a 'sudden fight' over a trivial 'nali' dispute, without any premeditation or pre-existing enmity pointing towards an intention to kill.
The weapon used was a 'lathi', considered an agricultural implement, not specifically chosen as a deadly weapon.
The appellant inflicted only a 'single blow'.
Considering these factors (sudden fight, no premeditation, trivial cause, single blow, nature of weapon), the Court concluded that the case falls under Culpable Homicide Not Amounting to Murder.
The Court analyzed Exception 4 to Section 300 IPC (sudden fight) and found the circumstances aligned with it.

The Court differentiated between intention and knowledge. While the appellant may not have intended to cause death or the specific fatal injury (negating S.302 and S.304 Part I), he possessed the knowledge that hitting someone on the head with a lathi was likely to cause death.

Therefore, the Court held that the appropriate conviction was under Section 304 Part II IPC (culpable homicide committed with knowledge that the act is likely to cause death, but without intention to cause death or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death).
